{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient presents with a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on her right thigh that has slowly increased in size over the past weeks. On examination, the lesion is a hyperpigmented papule that retracts when squeezed. This is consistent with the clinical presentation of a dermatofibroma, which is a benign skin lesion characterized by a firm, hyperpigmented papule or nodule that often has a central dimple or depression. Cherry hemangiomas are typically red, dome-shaped papules that do not retract when squeezed. Actinic keratosis presents as rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas of the skin. Seborrheic keratosis presents as well-demarcated, raised, waxy, stuck-on lesions that are often brown or black in color.", "answer_choice": "A"}
